You found me lying in the road down yonder, after a stupid accident that might have happened to any other careless tramp, and which scarcely gave me a claim to a bed in the county hospital, much less under this kindly roof. It was not my fault, as you know, that all this did not come out sooner; but while it does n't lessen your generosity, it does n't lessen my debt, and although I cannot hope to ever repay you, I can at least keep the score from running on. utterance: How could I? They must have all left the house as soon as it began. I was talking to- to M. l'Hommadieu, and he suddenly left.
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: D' ye mean to say that them d―d French half-breeds stampeded and left yer there alone?
speaker: the farm laborer

utterance: But you don't tell me what it was?
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: An earthquake,
speaker: the farm laborer

utterance: and if it had lasted ten seconds longer it would have shook the whole shanty down and left you under it. Yer kin tell that to them, if they don't know it, but from the way they made tracks to the fields, I reckon they did. They 're coming now.
speaker: the farm laborer

utterance: Oh, here you are!
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: We were wondering where you had run to, and were getting quite concerned. Emile was looking for you everywhere.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: Emile?
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: looking for me?
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Yes,
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: he says he started to run with you, but you got ahead and slipped out of the garden door or something of the kind,
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: You know one scarcely knows what one does at such times, and it must have been frightfully strange to you—and he's been quite distracted, lest you should have wandered away. Adele, run and tell him Miss Mallory has been here under the oak all the time.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: And you went back into the house to look for us when all was over,
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: and that stupid yokel Zake brought you out again. He need n't have clutched your arm so closely, my dear, — I must speak to the major about his excessive familiarity but I suppose I shall be told that that is American freedom. I call it 'a liberty.'
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: Of course, it's an upset - and you 're confused still.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: That's nothing. They say, dear, it's perfectly well known that no two people's recollections of these things ever are the same.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: It's really ridiculous the contradictory stories one hears. Is n't it, Emile?
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: It's all over now,
speaker: Emile

utterance: and except the chimneys and some fallen plaster there's really no damage done. But I'm afraid they have caught it pretty badly at the mission, and at San Francisco in those tall, flashy, rattle-trap buildings they 're putting up. I've just sent off one of the men for news.
speaker: Emile

utterance: I must telegraph to my father at once,
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: he is there.
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: You had better wait until the messenger returns and hear his news,
speaker: Emile

utterance: If the shock was only a slight one in San Francisco, your father might not understand you, and would be alarmed.
speaker: Emile

utterance: You surely will not desert us now?
speaker: Emile

utterance: Please don't,
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: I'm so worried,
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Only imagine you're picnicking, and you'll enjoy it as most people usually enjoy those horrid al fresco entertainments. I don't believe there's the slightest real necessity for it, but,
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: the Irish and Chinese servants are so demoralized now, they would n't stay indoors with us.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: It's a common practice here, I believe, for a day or two after the shock, and it gives time to put things right again and clear up. The old, one-storied, Spanish houses with walls three feet thick, and built round a courtyard or patio, were much safer. It's only when the Americans try to improve upon the old order of things with their pinchbeck shams and stucco that Providence interferes like this to punish them.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: You can't get across there, miss.
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: But you seem to have got over,
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Yes, but it was further up the field. I reckoned that the split might be deeper but not so broad in the rock outcrop over there than in the adobe here. I found it so and jumped it.
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: I'm afraid you must have been badly shaken and a little frightened up there before the chimneys came down?
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: No,
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: I was n't frightened. I did n't even know it was an earthquake.
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Ah!
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: that was because you were a stranger. It's odd they 're all like that. I suppose it's because nobody really expects or believes in the unlooked-for thing, and yet that's the thing that always happens. And then, of course, that other affair, which really is serious, startled you the more.
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: I don't know what you mean,
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: What other affair?
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Why, the well.
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: The well?
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Yes; the artesian well has stopped.
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: Did n't the major tell you?
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: No,
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: He was away; I have n't seen him yet.
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Well, the flow of water has ceased completely. That's what I'm here for. The major sent for me, and I've been to examine it.
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: And is that stoppage so very important?
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: If it's lost entirely, it means ruin for the ranch,
speaker: the young inventor

utterance: You need not telegraph to your father,
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: he has already telegraphed to you for news; as you were out, and the messenger was waiting an answer, we opened the dispatch, and sent one, telling him that you were all right, and that he need not hurry here on your account. So you are satisfied, I hope.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: You don't really mean to say, major,
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: that instead of sending to San Francisco for some skilled master-mechanic, you are going to listen to the vagaries of a conceited, half-educated farm-laborer, and employ him?
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: You might as well call in some of those wizards or water-witches at once.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: If his conclusions are as clear and satisfactory to-morrow as they were to-day, I shall certainly try to secure his services.
speaker: Major Randolph

utterance: Then I can only say I would prefer the water-witch. He at least would not represent a class of neighbors who have made themselves systematically uncivil and disagreeable to us.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: I am afraid, Josephine, we have not tried to make ourselves particularly agreeable to them,
speaker: Major Randolph

utterance: If that can only be done by admitting their equality, I prefer they should remain uncivil. Only let it be understood, major, that if you choose to take this Tom-theploughboy to mend your well, you will at least keep him there while he is on the property.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: Why, he's very handsome when his face is clean, and his hands are small and not at all hard. And he does n't talk the least bit queer or common.
speaker: Adele Randolph

utterance: where did you see him, and what do you know about his hands?
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: Or has the major already presented you to him?
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: No, but
speaker: Adele Randolph

utterance: when you sent me to look after Miss Mallory, I came up to him just after he had spoken to her, and he stopped to ask me how we all were, and if Miss Mallory was really frightened by the earthquake, and he shook hands for good afternoon - that's all.
speaker: Adele Randolph

utterance: And who taught you to converse with common strangers and shake hands with them?
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: Nobody, mamma; but I thought if Miss Mallory, who is a young lady, could speak to him, so could I, who am not out yet.
speaker: Adele Randolph

utterance: We won't discuss this any further at present,
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: The earthquake seems to have shaken down in this house more than the chimneys.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: Do you want to go, or do you want to stay here? Do you like these people, or do you not?
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: You are wrong, I tell you, a thousand times wrong. The girl is simply upset by this earthquake. It's a great pity her father did n't come instead of telegraphing.
speaker: Major Randolph

utterance: And by Jove, rather than hear any more of this, I'll send for him myself,
speaker: Major Randolph

utterance: And the girl won't thank you, and you '11 be a fool for your pains,
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: But according to your own ideas of propriety, Mallory ought to be the first one to be consulted—and by me, too.
speaker: Major Randolph

utterance: Not in this case. Of course, before any actual engagement is on, you can speak of Emile's attentions.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: But suppose Mallory has other views.
speaker: Major Randolph

utterance: Suppose he declines the honor. The man is no fool.
speaker: Major Randolph

utterance: Thank you.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: But for that very reason he must. Listen to me, major; if he does n't care to please his daughter for her own sake, he will have to do so for the sake of decency. Yes, I tell you, she has thoroughly compromised herself — quite enough, if it is ever known, to spoil any other engagement her father may make. Why, ask Adele! The day of the earthquake she absolutely had the audacity to send him out of the room upstairs into your study for her fan, and then follow him up there alone.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: The servants knew it. I knew it, for I was in her room at the time with Father Antonio.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: The earthquake made it plain to everybody.
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: Decline it! No. Mr. Mallory will think twice about it before he does that. What's that? Who's there?
speaker: Mrs. Randolph

utterance: I am afraid I will have to trouble you once more,
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Could you give me any kind of a conveyance that would take me to San José at once?
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: I did not take a buggy from the house,
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: for I left early, and did not want to disturb them. In fact, they don't know that I am gone. I was worried at not hearing news from my father in San Francisco since the earthquake, and I thought I would run down to San José to inquire without putting them to any trouble.
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Anything will do that you have ready, if I can take it at once.
speaker: Rose Mallory

utterance: Excuse me, but I thought every one was out
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: I've only just come, and would you mind, as you are here, giving me a lift with this table?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: Certainly
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Then you have changed all the furniture, and put up these things?
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance:
Yes, the room was really something too awful.
It looks better now, don't you think?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: A hundred per cent. Look here, I'll tell you what you've done. You've set the furniture to work! It was simply lying still — with no return to anybody on the investment.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance:
Yes, I wonder Mr. Robert Rushbrook don't look at it in that way. It is a shame that all these pretty things and you know they are really good and valuable should n't show what they are.
But I suppose everybody here accepts the fact that this man simply buys them because they are val uable, and nobody interferes, and is content to humor him, laugh at him, and feel superior. It don't strike me as quite fair, does it you?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance:
Have you seen the ladies'
boudoir? You know, the room fitted with knick-knacks and pretty things some of 'em bought from old collections in Europe, by fellows who knew what they were; but perhaps, did n't know exactly what ladies cared for.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: I merely glanced in there when I first came, for there was such a queer lot of women - I'm told he is n't very particular in that way that I did n't stay.
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: And you did n't think they might be just as valuable and good as some of the furniture, if they could have been pulled around and put into shape, or set in a corner, eh?
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Some of them looked as if they had been pulled around, as you say, and had n't been improved by it.
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: There's no one there now, come and take a look at it.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: We 've just about seven minutes yet; if you'd like to pull and haul these things around, I'll help you.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: I'm quite content with what I've done in my own room, where I have no one's taste to consult but my own. I hardly know how Mr. Robert Rushbrook, or his lady friends, might like my operating here. Tell me something about our host -but first look is n't that pretty?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: There is n't much to be changed down there, is there?
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: No, not unless Mr. Robert Rushbrook took it into his head to roof it in, and somebody was ready with a contract to do it. But what do you know of him? Remember, I'm quite a stranger here.
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: You came with Charley Leyton?
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: With Mrs. Leyton's party.
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance:
But it seems that we don't know whether Mr. Robert Rushbrook wants us here or not, till he comes.
And the drollest thing about it is that they're all so perfectly frank in saying so.
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: Charley and he are old friends, and you'll do well to trust to their judgment.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance:
Look here, you'll meet a man here to-night — or he 'll be sure to meet you who'll tell you all about Mr. Robert Rushbrook. He's a smart chap, knows everybody and talks well. His name is Jack Somers; he is a great ladies' man.
He can talk to you about these sort of things, too, just as well as he can talk of people. Been in Europe, too.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance:
I know him- I met him at Mr.
Leyton's. He has already talked of Mr.
Robert Rushbrook, but, I'd like to have the opinion of others. Yours, now, I fancy would be quite independent.
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: You stick to what Jack Somers has said, good or bad, and you won't be far wrong,
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Well, my dear, it seems we are to stay. Leyton says Mr. Robert Rushbrook won't hear of our going.
speaker: Mrs. Leyton

utterance: Does that mean that your husband takes the whole opera troupe over to your house in exchange?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: Don't be satirical, but congratulate yourself on your opportunity of seeing an awfully funny gathering. I would n't have you miss it for the world. It's the most characteristic thing out.
speaker: Mrs. Leyton

utterance: Characteristic of what?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: Of Mr. Robert Rushbrook, of course. Nobody else would conceive of getting together such a lot of queer people.
speaker: Mrs. Leyton

utterance: But don't it strike you that we 're a part of the lot?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: Perhaps. No doubt that's the reason why Jack Somers is coming over, and is so anxious that you should stay. I can't imagine why else he should rave about Miss Grace Nevil as he does. Come, Grace, no New York or Philadelphia airs, here! Consider your uncle's interests with this capitalist, to say nothing of ours. Because you're a millionaire and have been accustomed to riches from your birth, don't turn up your nose at our unpampered appetites. Besides, Jack Somers is Mr. Robert Rushbrook's particular friend, and he may think your criticisms unkind.
speaker: Mrs. Leyton

utterance: But is Mr. Somers such a great friend of Mr. Robert Rushbrook's?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: Why, of course. Mr. Robert Rushbrook consults him about all these things; gives him carte blanche to invite whom he likes and order what he likes, and trusts his taste and judg ment implicitly.
speaker: Mrs. Leyton

utterance: Then this gathering is Mr. Somers's selection?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance:
How preposterous you are, Grace. Of course not. Only Somers's idea of what is pleasing to Mr. Robert Rushbrook, gotten up with a taste and discretion all his own. You know Somers is a gentleman, educated at West Point traveled all over Europe you might have met him there; and Mr. Robert Rushbrook
- well, you have only to see him to know what he is. Don't you understand?
speaker: Mrs. Leyton

utterance: No.
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: I am to have the pleasure of taking you in, Miss Nevil. It's my one compensation for the dreadful responsibility just thrust upon me. Our host has been suddenly called away, and I am left to take his place.
speaker: Jack Somers

utterance: From what I hear this is no new function of yours; that is, if there really is a Mr. Robert Rushbrook. I am inclined to think him a myth.
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: You make me wish he were, but as I could n't reign at all, except in his stead, I shall look to you to lend your rightful grace to my borrowed dignity.
speaker: Jack Somers

utterance:
It reminds me, of ole Kernel Frisbee, of Robertson County, one of the purlitest men.
I ever struck. When he knew a feller was very dry, he'd jest set the decanter afore him, and managed to be called outer the room on bus'ness. Now, Bob Rushbrook's about as white a man as that. He's jest the feller, who, knowing you and me might feel kinder restrained about indulging our appetites afore him, kinder drops out easy, and leaves us alone.
speaker: a gentleman from Siskyou

utterance: I should be glad to receive the salary that Mr. Robert Rushbrook pays his chef, and still happier to know how to earn it as fairly.
speaker: Jack Somers

utterance: But is his skill entirely appreciated here?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance:
Perfectly. Our friend from Siskyou over there appreciates that pâté which he cannot name as well as I do. Mr. Robert Rushbrook himself is the only exception, yet I fancy that even his simplicity and regularity in feeding is as much a matter of business with him as any defect in his earlier education. In his eyes, his chef's greatest qualification is his promptness and fertility.
Have you noticed that ornament before you?
speaker: Jack Somers

utterance:
It bears your initials, you see. It was conceived and executed since you arrived rather, I should say, since it was known that you would honor us with your company.
The greatest difficulty encountered was to find out what your initials were.
speaker: Jack Somers

utterance: And I suppose, that the same fertile mind which conceived the design eventually provided the initials?
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: That is our secret.
speaker: Jack Somers

utterance:
Pears to me, ladies and gentlemen, and feller pardners, that on an occasion like this, suthin' oughter be said of the man who got it up whose money paid for it, and who ain't here to speak for himself, except by deputy. Yet you all know that's Bob Rushbrook's style - he ain't here, because he 's full of some other plan or improvements and it's like him to start suthin' of this kind, give it its aim and purpose, and then stand aside to let somebody else run it for him.
There ain't no man livin' ez hez, so to speak, more fast horses ready saddled for riding, and more fast men ready spurred to ride 'em, - whether to win his races or run his errands. There ain't no man livin' ez knows better how to make other men's games his, or his game seem to be other men's. And from Jack Somers smilin' over there, ez knows where to get the best wine that Bob pays for, and knows how to run this yer show for Bob, at Bob's expense we're all contented. Ladies and gentlemen, we 're all contented. We stand, so to speak, on the cards he's dealt us. What may be his little game, it ain't for us to say; but whatever it is, we're in it. Gentlemen and ladies, we'll drink Bob's health!
speaker: a gentleman from Siskyou

utterance: Mr. Robert Rushbrook returned sooner than he expected, but unfortunately, as he always retires early, he has only time to say 'goodnight' to you before he goes.
speaker: Mrs. Leyton

utterance: Well, Miss Nevil, I hope Jack Somers satisfied your curiosity?
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Yes; but there was a speech by a gentleman from Siskyou that struck me as being nearer to the purpose.
speaker: Grace Nevil

utterance: That's so, I heard it as I came in. I don't know but you u're right.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Mr. Leyton is in your study, sir; he will stay to dinner.
speaker: James

utterance: All right.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: I think, sir, he wants to talk. At least, sir, he asked me if you would likely come downstairs before your company arrived.
speaker: James

utterance: Ah! Well, tell the others I'm dining on business, and set dinner for two in the blue room.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: James

utterance: And what is all this affair about the dinner?
speaker: Signora Pegrelli

utterance: Well, what do you think of her?
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: She cost me already ten thousand dollars, and I suppose I'll have to eventually fix up a separate room for her somewhere,
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: I should certainly advise it, for really, Mr. Robert Rushbrook, you know that something is due to the respectable people who come here, and any of them are likely to see
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance:
Ah! you think she hasn't got on clothes enough.
Why, look here, old man she's one of the Virtues, and that's the rig in which they always travel. She's a 'Temperance' or a 'Charity' or a 'Resignation,' or something of that kind. You'll find her name there in French somewhere at the foot of the marble.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: I was referring to some woman who stood in that doorway just now, and addressed me rather familiarly, thinking it was you.
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance: Oh, the Signora, well, you saw her at Los Osos last summer. Likely she did think you were me.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Yes, but the fact is that Miss Nevil had talked of coming here with me this evening to see you on her own affairs, and it would n't have been exactly the thing for her to meet that woman.
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance:
She would n't, nor would you, if you had gone into the parlor as Miss Nevil would have done.
But look here! If that's the reason why you did n't bring her, send for her at once; my coachman can take a card from you; the brougham's all ready to fetch her, and there you are. She'll see only you and me.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: No matter now. I can tell you her business, I fancy; and in fact, I came here to speak of it, quite independently of her.
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance: That won't do, Leyton. One or the other interview is unnecessary; it wastes time, and is n't business. Better have her present, even if she don't say a word.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Yes, but not in this matter; it's about Somers. You know he's been very attentive to her ever since her uncle left her here to recruit her health, and I think she fancies him. Well, although she's independent and her own mistress, as you know, Mrs. Leyton and I are somewhat responsible for her acquaintance with Somand for that matter so are you; and as my wife thinks it means a marriage, we ought to know something more positive about Somers's prospects. Now, all we really know is that he 's a great friend of yours; that you trust a good deal to him; ers, that he manages your social affairs; that you treat him as a son or nephew, and it's generally believed that he 's as good as provided for by you- eh? Did you speak?
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance: No. Go on.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Well, that's the belief everybody has, and you've not contradicted it. And on that we 've taken the responsibility of not interfering with Somers's attentions.
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance: Well?
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: Well, you see I must ask you positively if you have done anything, or are you going to do anything for him?
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance: Well, what do you call this marriage?
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: I don't understand you.
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance: Look here, Leyton, Jack Somers has brains, knowledge of society, tact, accomplishments, and good looks: that's his capital as much as mine is money. I employ him: that's his advertisement, recommendation, and credit. Now, on the strength of this, as you say, Miss Nevil is willing to invest in him; I don't see what more can be done.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: But if her uncle don't think it enough?
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance: She's independent, and has money for both.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook

utterance: But if she thinks she 's been deceived, and changes her mind?
speaker: Mr. Leyton

utterance:
Leyton, you don't know Miss Nevil.
Whatever that girl undertakes she's weighed fully, and goes through with. If she 's trusted him enough to marry him, money won't stop her; if she thinks she's been deceived, you'll never know it.
speaker: Mr. Robert Rushbrook
